title: 1. Introduction to JavaScript
explanation: JavaScript is a versatile, high-level programming language that is one of the core technologies of the World Wide Web, alongside HTML and CSS. It enables interactive web pages and is an essential part of web applications. You can run JavaScript in the browser's console or within a `<script>` tag in your HTML.
example:
// This is a JavaScript comment
console.log("Hello from JavaScript!");

title: 2. Variables: var, let, and const
explanation: Variables are containers for storing data. In modern JavaScript, we use `let` for variables that can be reassigned and `const` for variables that should not be reassigned (constants). The older `var` keyword has different scoping rules and is generally avoided.

title: 3. Data Types
explanation: JavaScript has several primitive data types: `String` (text), `Number` (for both integers and floats), `Boolean` (true or false), `null` (intentional absence of value), and `undefined` (a variable that has not been assigned a value). It also has complex data types like `Object`.
example:
let greeting = "Hello"; // String
let score = 100; // Number
let isActive = true; // Boolean

title: 4. Functions
explanation: Functions are blocks of code designed to perform a particular task. A function is executed when 'something' invokes it (calls it). Functions are defined with the `function` keyword, or as an arrow function `() => {}`.

title: 5. Arrays
explanation: Arrays are special variables which can hold more than one value at a time. They are ordered collections, and you can access elements using a zero-based index.
example:
const fruits = ["Apple", "Banana", "Cherry"];
console.log(fruits[0]); // Outputs: Apple

fruits.push("Orange"); // Adds an element to the end
console.log(fruits.length); // Outputs: 4

title: 6. Objects
explanation: Objects are collections of key/value pairs. They are used to store related data and are a fundamental concept in JavaScript. You can access properties using dot notation or bracket notation.

title: 7. DOM Manipulation
explanation: The Document Object Model (DOM) is a programming interface for web documents. It represents the page so that programs can change the document structure, style, and content. JavaScript can be used to manipulate the DOM, for example, to change the text of an HTML element.

title: 8. Event Handling
explanation: JavaScript can be used to react to user events like clicks, mouse movements, or key presses. You use `addEventListener` to listen for a specific event on an element and then run a function when that event occurs.

title: 9. Conditional Statements
explanation: Conditional statements are used to perform different actions based on different conditions. The primary conditionals are `if`, `else if`, and `else`, which allow you to control the flow of your program.

title: 10. Asynchronous JavaScript (Async/Await)
explanation: JavaScript is single-threaded, but you can perform long network requests or other operations without blocking the main thread using asynchronous code. `async/await` is modern syntax that makes it easier to work with Promises and write asynchronous code that looks and behaves like synchronous code.
